3.2.5 Diffusion Model
[Also describe the used diffusion model]






Tip



You can also work with equations. Example: (Equation 3.1) is a mathematical model that seeks to explain the behavior of financial derivatives, most commonly options:
\[
\frac{\partial \mathrm C}{ \partial \mathrm t } + \frac{1}{2}\sigma^{2} \mathrm S^{2}
\frac{\partial^{2} \mathrm C}{\partial \mathrm C^2}
  + \mathrm r \mathrm S \frac{\partial \mathrm C}{\partial \mathrm S}\ =
  \mathrm r \mathrm C
\tag{3.1}\]






Knuth, Donald E. 1984. “Literate Programming.” Comput. J. 27 (2): 97–111. https://doi.org/10.1093/comjnl/27.2.97.
